column4: Where to store a foreign DEB program package on my own Gutsy computer?
what program do you want to install?
I do not want to install a program. First I want to download a package.
what do you mean by "foreign"? Is it not in the repositories?
No, it is not. It is in sourceforge.
are you sure it is a DEB package for Ubuntu? Otherwise it may not work. Just grab it, save it wherever you want, like your home directory and install it. What was your question again?

I have put my question at the outset at 20:10 GMT +1. --  It is a DEB program package. Do you know what a DEB program package is. It is not in the Ubuntu repositories, probably intentionally because it might interfere with upstart.
I was just asking if you solved your problem.  What does this program do (the one you want to download)?
It provides the programs s2ram, s2disk and s2both. I need s2ram for analyzing. Sourceforge says: "It provides Linux suspend."
maybe it is a a very new program not fully tested by the Debian distribution.

I suspect that you are not well-informed. s2ram is a rather old program whose creation was suggested by Linux Torvalds himself. Linus Torwalds himself wrote an instruction for use. You will find it in the kernel documentation.
I didn't know. Most of the people in here are not experts, please provide some background when asking some question of this kind.  Maybe the program is obsolete now.
README shows a lot of changes made during this summer.
you mean in the SourceForge page?   Or maybe it is updated with the kernel. Why would they provide a deb package for a small utility?
I thought there was a DEB program package providing s2ram, s2disk and s2both altogether. But there is none.
I just got an answer from one of the Ubuntu kernel developers: " We use the acpi-support scripts in gutsy and pm-utils in hardy." So I will re-arrange my thinking and troubleshooting accordingly.
so,  what happened to the utilities? They are no longer used?
My interpretation is: s2ram is no longer to be used as an analytical tool for Gutsy and Hardy. Rather, other tools are provided.
I guess those things like USB controllers, to which you attach devices.
what? Read the manual? This is usually not the place to discuss kernel hacking.
Your message is not helpful.
perhaps some program you downloaded from the university
Yes indeed. But so far I was not able to figure out which one.
